item.title: Ticket #3762 (Trying to get property of non-object) created
item.dc:creator: darkfate
item.description:
I don't have notices disabled in PHP since I'm working in a development environment. I don't know if this notice comes up anywhere else, but the page where you create the wp-config file it says:

Notice: Trying to get property of non-object in C:\Apache2\htdocs\wp\wp-includes\functions.php on line 1316

I think this is a PHP5 specific thing, but I'm not sure. It may be related to the way PHP5 uses destruct to shutdown functions in reverse order.

item.title: Ticket #3760 (Page Management Page order backwards in 2.1) created
item.dc:creator: here
item.description:
Page Management Page order backwards in 2.1

As described and solved at ​forum topic 102764: Page Management Page order backwards in 2.1

The admin page wp-admin/edit-pages.php , "Page Management" lists pages in an order different from that specified by 'page order' variable. This was not a problem in 2.0.7.

item.title: Ticket #3635 (RSS feed and relative url gives warning) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
I think Mark was mistaken in that instance, because he was linking to the same document.

See: ​http://www.apps.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3986.html#sec-4.4

What's really interesting is that people are now using those fragments as permalinks for AJAX-powered applications, because you can change that fragment in the location bar of the browser without refreshing the page. But then what happens if someone visits a URL that is [baseurl]#fragment1 and then from that URL tries to go to [baseurl]#fragment2 ? RFC3986 says that the browser shouldn't issue a new request, because it is considered a same document reference.

So, clever, but not foolproof.

As for this issue, we could fix it by running a preg_replace() filter on RSS content, but I don't know if it's worth it.

item.title: Ticket #968 ("Edit timestamp" form needs tabindexes) updated
item.dc:creator: foolswisdom

item.title: Ticket #3635 (RSS feed and relative url gives warning) closed
item.dc:creator: foolswisdom
item.description:
wontfix:

Closing as WONTFIX, real feed readers that can't handle this are broken.

snakefoot and Otto42 thank you for participating! This is an interesting topic to me.

I recall reading recently:

"However, I will note in passing that this particular relative link is a full pathname that is only relative to the domain, so even if I did include this link in an RSS feed (which I haven’t), it shouldn’t present a problem for feed readers. There are only a finite number of reasonable choices for guessing the base URL of a relative link in an RSS feed — the feed URL, the entry URL, or the channel URL — and even though no RSS spec defines the right one, in this case they all share the same domain so they would all resolve to the same (correct) destination. If your feed reader isn’t choosing any of those, then it’s *really* broken, and I find it difficult to believe that my feed is the first place you’ve had a problem."
​http://diveintomark.org/archives/2007/01/30/truth-hurts#comment-8130

item.title: Ticket #3678 (Apache 2 segmentation fault) updated
item.dc:creator: foolswisdom
item.description:
fwenzel, I looked at the stack trace and my searching did not immediately identify the problem. Most likely the problem is not WordPress. I did find out how this type of issue is generally investigated:
1) Search and then open a ticket with the distribution -- sounds like Debian in this case

  • Maintainer may be able to identify the issue or provide next step in investigation

2) Try using a older package of PHP to help isolate when the the problem was introduced
3) Once isolated the maintainer may try and get you to apply individual patches

Please let us know what the upstream ticket # is?

item.title: Ticket #3635 (RSS feed and relative url gives warning) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
This is because most feed readers have no certain way to resolve a relative reference to the correct webpage. Some feedreaders can be smart about it, most can't.

The short of it is that you should really always use absolute references, but there's nothing forcing you to do so. This is not really a solvable problem from Wordpress's perspective. Bad stuff in posts = bad stuff in feeds.

item.title: Ticket #3686 (index page gives 404 when using non-default permalinks) updated
item.dc:creator: jamesw
item.description:
Right, after check on a number of blogs on the same server, it appears that the common symptom is that their REQUEST_URI is set to the directory, they are in, not the relative path to index.php (See previous message).

However, I don't know how to reliably test for that, so I can't provide a patch for it.

item.title: Ticket #968 ("Edit timestamp" form needs tabindexes) reopened
item.dc:creator: justinbaeder
item.description:
As of WP2.1, this problem is back. Tabbing from timestamp month should take you to the year field, but instead it goes back to the post contents textarea. Same problem for the other timestamp fields.

If you click into one of the date fields, tabbing works as it should. However, if you check the "Edit Timestamp" box, then click a time field to edit, tabbing does not work as expected. Something about the checkbox interferes with the tabindex, causing each tab to jump back to the posting box.

item.title: Ticket #3678 (Apache 2 segmentation fault) updated
item.dc:creator: fwenzel
item.description: I just added a stack backtrace. I made four of them but they look similar. However I can't read much useful out of this. Does this make more sense to somebody else?
